data.title: What does an agile project manager do?
data.meta_description: An agile project manager is responsible for the day-to-day management of the project and fostering collaboration. This blog elaborates on this roles main responsibilities and the essential skills needed.
data.text:
Crucial to the success of any Agile endeavour is the Agile project manager, a central role responsible for bringing together separate elements to achieve project goals. The project manager has many responsibilities, prioritising adaptability, collaboration, and ensuring projects meet expectations. An Agile Project Manager is a multifaceted, intricate position requiring various skills and attributes.

The complex role isn't always easy to understand. Still, business success often relies on the agile project manager promoting collaboration across departments and empowering teams with understanding, communication and strong leadership. So, when everyone understands the manager role, projects are more likely to succeed, and Agile methodologies can be deployed effectively.

What is Agile Project Management?

Agile project management is a dynamic, iterative approach to project management that promotes flexibility, collaboration, and customer-centricity. Unlike traditional methodologies, which often follow a more rigid, linear path, the Agile framework embraces change and prioritises delivering incremental value to stakeholders for early and continuous delivery.

By fostering adaptive planning and cross-functional teamwork, Agile methods empower teams to respond swiftly to shifting requirements and market dynamics. Check out our comprehensive blog post to delve deeper into the principles, practices, and benefits of Agile Project Management.

In recent years, the popularity of Agile values has surged, signalling a paradigm shift in project management. Organisations in all sectors are now adopting Agile methods to improve their responsiveness and elevate customer satisfaction.

The Roles in Agile Project Teams

An Agile project team encompasses a range of essential roles that collectively drive projects to completion. Different teams may require a variation of the leading roles.

These roles, as outlined in the Agile Business Consortium's DSDM project framework, can include the Business Sponsor, who is responsible for the overall project, budget, and deliverables within the larger business framework; Visionary, who is responsible for the overall vision and direction; Technical Coordinator, who ensures that the solution is technically correct and meets requirements; Team Leader, leading small areas and detailed parts of the project; Business Analyst, working to identify opportunities and changes to the business as a whole which may impact the project; Solution Developer, takes the business requirements and uses them to inform the solution; Solution Tester, responsible for performance testing at every stage.

Agile teams often have diverse and varied roles tailored to project goals, fostering the idea of adaptability. Yet, amid these variations, the pivotal role of the agile project manager remains consistent, driving coordination and promoting agile principles.

What is an Agile Project Manager?

An Agile project manager is a multifaceted role that blends high-level leadership with facilitation in an Agile project environment. Their primary focus is on shaping the evolving working environment for the solution and fostering collaboration within the Solution Development Team. The project manager guides team members without imposing detailed project plans on the development process. Instead, they employ a facilitative approach, steering the project without exercising a strict "command and control" style.

The Project Manager's role is pivotal in ensuring project success, encompassing responsibilities from effective communication with stakeholders to overseeing high-level project planning and scheduling. Additionally, the Project Manager monitors progress, manages risks and issues, and encourages team empowerment and motivation.

Throughout the project's lifecycle, from foundations to deployment, the Project Manager remains central to maintaining effective coordination and communication.

Key Responsibilities of an Agile Project Manager

Agile Project Managers shoulder diverse critical responsibilities, which are different from traditional project manager positions. This role should be flexible and central to the agile workflow.

Responsibilities include:

Orchestrating the project's evolution through to the project's completion.

Promoting transparent communication and collaboration within the agile team.

Nurturing an environment where team members can self-organise and make decisions.

Providing coaching and training to facilitate Agile adoption and continuous improvement.

Aligning project objectives with broader organisational goals.

Facilitating effective cross-functional collaboration and integration.

Guiding the development team to create and follow a delivery plan.

Monitoring project progress and the project timeline.

Identifying roadblocks and addressing issues promptly.

Ensuring timely risk management and resolution of impediments.

Cultivating a culture of adaptability, innovation, and learning.

Balancing customer feedback and needs with technical constraints.

Encouraging continuous feedback loops to refine processes and deliverables.

Collaborating with stakeholders to gather and prioritise requirements.

Empowering the team to embrace change and adapt to evolving circumstances.

Championing Agile practices within the organisation.

The specific responsibilities of the agile Project Manager role will vary based on the particulars of the Agile environment, the nature of the project, and the business requirements.

What is the difference between a Traditional and Agile Project Manager?

The distinction between a Traditional and Agile Project Manager lies in their approach to project management:

Traditional Project Managers

Emphasises a "command and control" style, prescribing tasks and processes. Focuses on detailed upfront planning, aiming for a comprehensive project blueprint from the beginning. Primarily responsible for task distribution and overseeing individual contributions.

Agile Project Manager

Prioritises collaboration and adaptability, fostering teamwork and open communication. Embraces iterative, agile planning, allowing for flexible adjustments throughout the project. Encourages shared leadership within self-organising teams, empowering members to collectively drive decisions and outcomes.

The Essential Skills needed to be a Successful Agile Project Manager

Becoming a proficient Agile Project Manager involves honing a blend of technical, interpersonal, and leadership skills to guide projects successfully in the dynamic Agile landscape. Agile project managers hold the overarching responsibility for managing agile projects from beginning to end, requiring a range of unique and adaptable skills, including:

Strong Organisational Skills: Ability to manage complex projects, allocate resources effectively, and ensure tasks are completed on time.

Excellent Communication Skills: Proficiency in articulating ideas, needs, and progress across various levels of the organisation, promoting transparency.

Risk Management: Skill in identifying potential project risks, assessing their impact, and devising mitigation strategies.

Conflict Resolution: Ability to navigate disagreements and differences within the team, fostering a productive, agile environment and improving team effectiveness.

Adaptive Leadership: Capability to adjust leadership style based on the team's needs, encouraging autonomy and self-organisation.

Agile Expertise: An understanding of the Agile manifesto, and the four key values could be advantageous. In-depth familiarity with an Agile framework, such as the DSDM project management approach, along with Agile tools, is essential for successful implementation.

Flexibility: Capacity to navigate uncertainties and changes inherent in Agile working while focusing on goals.

Collaboration: Willingness to work closely with cross-functional teams, stakeholders, and customers to deliver value collaboratively.

Customer-Centric Approach: Focus on understanding and meeting customer needs, driving customer satisfaction and collaboration.

Decision-Making: Superior critical thinking capabilities and making informed and timely decisions.

Agile Project Management Certifications and Training

As Agile project management approaches continue to dominate project management, APMG offers a diverse range of leading certifications for learners to choose from. Our agile project management qualifications and training allow project managers to develop skills and learn agile approaches.

APMG agile courses and certifications:

• Agile Project Management (AgilePM): Learn how to apply the leading framework for Agile project delivery

• Agile Programme Management (AgilePgM): Discover how to create flexible agile programmes, capable of responding to shifts in business needs.

• Agile Business Analysis (AgileBA): Master the role of a Business Analyst in an Agile environment.

• Agile Change Agent: Build your practical ability in agile and change.

• Scrum: Learn how to get the best out of Scrum with Scrum Master and Product Owner training.

• DASA Dev ops: Transform your organisation's IT by implementing the DASA DevOps principles.

With an APMG qualification, project managers become adept at agile processes and popular agile methodologies gaining distinct competitive advantage.

Conclusion

As organisations increasingly recognise the need for flexibility, collaboration, and iterative progress, project managers have emerged as facilitators of this paradigm shift. By embracing the Agile mindset, project managers are not only overseeing projects but actively guiding teams towards adaptability and customer-centricity.

Ultimately, by embodying the Agile ethos and cultivating an environment that nurtures Agile values, project managers pave the way for successful, innovative, and customer-driven projects in the dynamic modern landscape.
